[She]21-elinor knew it was wrong to let another suffer in [one]1228-one ’s place and spoke bravely out . “[313-you] [He]313-you is not selfish , [he]313-you is going to take care of [my]0-i letter . ” [Leslie]24-leslie [himself]24-leslie coloured at this sudden shifting of the ground under [his]24-leslie feet , and [Laura]26-laura burst into that insolent laugh which bows down all but such as can laugh insolently in return . The moisture which precedes tears came into [Elinor]21-elinor ’s eyes . [She]21-elinor turned partly away , and [Leslie]24-leslie could not but gaze on the innocent pretty picture [she]21-elinor made . “[313-you] Do n’t let [me]0-i detain [you]313-you , [Mr. Letter‐]40-mr. letter‐ carrier ” said [Laura]26-laura . “[0-i] [I]0-i was not aware of [[your]313-you new office]314-your new office . [You]313-you came here as [an independent gentleman]315-an independent gentleman , but [a new character ......]316-a new character ...... ” “[316-a new character ......] Does what ? ” said [Leslie]24-leslie , after a silent pause . “[316-a new character ......] Nay , nothing at all — only [I]0-i thought [you]313-you were not listening to [me]0-i , [your]313-you attention seemed elsewhere . ” “[313-you] Oh ! do n’t doubt that whatever [Miss Chanson]29-miss chanson says , or even hints , has [my]0-i best attention and consideration . [I]0-i ’ll go now — pray excuse [me]0-i . ” “[0-i] By all means . [I]0-i wish [you]313-you to ...... do as [you]313-you like , ” said [Laura]26-laura , abruptly ; and [he]313-you saw [her]21-elinor lip tremble . “[21-elinor] [Poor Elinor]21-elinor ! ” thought [he]313-you , looking back , “[21-elinor] what will [you]21-elinor make of the scolding [you]21-elinor are about to get . ” And a scolding it was , indeed . Not that [Laura]26-laura intended it when [she]26-laura began , but [she]26-laura lost [her]26-laura self‐command as [she]26-laura talked ; and the anguish which [she]26-laura endured , through [Elinor]21-elinor , made [her]26-laura blind to the innocence , and deaf to the guileless purity of [the young girl]107-the young girl . “[21-elinor] [I]0-i do n’t know , [Elinor]21-elinor , ” [she]0-i began , “[21-elinor] whether [you]21-elinor think it quite proper to send [one ’s acquaintances all over [the country]318-the country]317-one ’s acquaintances all over the country on [your]21-elinor errands ; for [my]0-i part , [I]0-i know [I]0-i should be heartily ashamed of doing so . ” “[0-i] Oh , [[my]0-i dear]1127-my dear [Miss Chanson]29-miss chanson , was it wrong ? ” “[29-miss chanson] Heartily ashamed , that ’s all [I]0-i can say ; and so would [any one with the least sense of decency]320-any one with the least sense of decency , ” said [Laura]26-laura , beginning to tremble . “[29-miss chanson] But [you]21-elinor have [your]21-elinor own notions , doubtless . ” “[21-elinor] No , indeed , indeed ! ” “[21-elinor] And to give [yourself]21-elinor such airs in [[another person]321-another person ’s house]322-another person ’s house — commanding everything as if it were [your]21-elinor own , and more than if it were [your]21-elinor own . The horses , [the servants]1262-the servants , [the very guests]324-the very guests , all to be at [your]21-elinor command . [You]21-elinor are to send [[our]325-our guests]326-our guests just to carry [your]21-elinor letters to the post . [I]0-i think what serves [our]325-our letters might serve [yours]21-elinor . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i wish [I]0-i had known — [I]0-i am very , very sorry . ” “[0-i] What made [you]21-elinor fix on [Mr. Leslie]24-leslie for [[your]21-elinor confidant]327-your confidant , pray . Was it because [you]21-elinor found [him]24-leslie [here]1135-here , interested ...... [I]0-i mean that [you]21-elinor thought [him]24-leslie not likely to devote [himself]24-leslie sufficiently to [your]21-elinor superior merits , unless specially invited . [You]21-elinor need not cry , it is no use to pretend one thing and do another ; [men]1230-men are always taken in by anybody who gives [themselves]1230-men the trouble , and for [my]0-i part , [I]0-i warn [you]21-elinor that [they]1230-men will only despise [you]21-elinor , [they]1230-men will find out ..... in fact , [I]0-i see through [you]21-elinor as if [you]21-elinor were glass . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i wish [I]0-i could see [myself]0-i and know how [I]0-i have offended [you]21-elinor , ” said [Elinor]21-elinor , weeping . “[0-i] [Me]0-i offended ! oh , dear [me]0-i , not [I]0-i ! [Mr. Leslie]24-leslie is as perfectly indifferent to [me]0-i , as [you]21-elinor are . [I]0-i only warn [you]21-elinor for [your]21-elinor own sake that [you]21-elinor are acting as [not another young girl in all the whole of [England]6-england]330-not another young girl in all the whole of england would dare to act . ” So saying , [Laura]26-laura fled from [the room]104-the room , for [she]26-laura could contain [herself]26-laura no longer ; and while [Elinor]21-elinor wept silently in [the library]229-the library , [Laura]26-laura sobbed aloud in [her]26-laura boudoir , the door of which [she]26-laura had banged behind [her]26-laura and fastened with a double turn of the key . [Elinor]21-elinor had a guiltless conscience in [her]21-elinor favour , and recovered first ; but [she]21-elinor was very unhappy , and being ignorant as to what [she]21-elinor had done wrong [she]21-elinor resolved first to beg [Mr. Leslie]24-leslie ’s pardon , and then to entreat [his]24-leslie assistance in explaining to [her]21-elinor the course of conduct which would be doing right . [She]21-elinor stole up the back staircase to [[her]21-elinor room]1295-her room ; bathed [her]21-elinor face as [she]21-elinor had often done in [[the pupils]1296-the pupils ’ room in [the Convent]127-the convent]1297-the pupils ’ room in the convent , when [she]21-elinor had been scolded and wanted to avoid the imputation of resenting the scolding ; and putting on [her]21-elinor bonnet and gray cloak , went dejectedly down again , and glided by the most sequestered ways [she]21-elinor could find , towards the gate of [the park]1299-the park by which [she]21-elinor believed [Mr. Leslie]24-leslie would return . Here [she]21-elinor sat down , patiently to wait for [him]24-leslie , and screened [herself]21-elinor from observation by choosing [her]21-elinor seat among some drooping elms , whose long branches , as one sees sometimes with the elm tree , had turned downwards soon after leaving the stem , and bowed themselves to the ground , as if kneeling . But , patient as [she]21-elinor was , and used to waiting , the length of time [she]21-elinor remained there , during which there was nothing coming , made [her]21-elinor first uneasy , and at last anxious . [She]21-elinor got up and walked into [the road]169-the road , whence [she]21-elinor could command a long sight of [the highway]1301-the highway beyond the gates , and still , when all was blank , returned to [her]21-elinor seat , and resumed the paper‐mark [she]21-elinor was plaiting in the shape of a cross . [The woman who kept [the lodge]1303-the lodge]1302-the woman who kept the lodge had seen [this manœuvre]1304-this manœuvre more than once , and at last , in the civility of [her]1302-the woman who kept the lodge heart , came out as [Elinor]21-elinor again looked down [the road]169-the road , and asked if [she]1302-the woman who kept the lodge was pleased to be waiting for some body . “[0-i] No , ” said [Elinor]21-elinor ; “[0-i] only [I]0-i think [Mr. Leslie]24-leslie will return this way from [Cantleton]7-cantleton ; ” and as [she]0-i said [his]24-leslie name , [she]0-i blushed deeply as [young girls]1306-young girls will do , at sight or at speaking of [a young acquaintance of the opposite sex]1307-a young acquaintance of the opposite sex , though as heart‐whole as a bird just fledged , on the edge of its nest . [The old woman]1308-the old woman laughed in a motherly way . “[24-leslie] Oh ! that ’s it , ” said [she]1308-the old woman . “[24-leslie] [I]0-i did not know , [miss]331-miss ; [you]331-miss will be pleased to forgive [me]0-i , ” and [she]1308-the old woman withdrew to [[her]1308-the old woman cottage]1309-her cottage , and [Elinor]21-elinor to [her]21-elinor tree , puzzled again , and but half liking what [she]21-elinor did not understand in [the old woman]1308-the old woman . It was an hour and a half after [she]0-i had come to [the spot]1311-the spot , when [she]0-i heard the trot of horses ’ feet , at which [her]0-i heart gave a bound , but directly the sound of wheels became audible , and the next bound of [her]0-i heart was what might be called in the opposite direction . [She]0-i went further under the trees , and saw [Laura]26-laura and [others on horseback]1312-others on horseback , and [a carriage]1313-a carriage following , all making towards [the Lodge]9-the lodge at a good , exhilarating pace . As [they]1314-they approached [it]9-the lodge , [she]0-i perceived [Mr. Leslie]24-leslie coming in the opposite direction , and [both parties]1315-both parties stopped and had some communion together . What [they]1314-they said [she]0-i did not know , but [she]0-i perceived some laughter , some gestures of expostulation , and that [Laura]26-laura , after great apparent earnestness , suddenly jerked away [her]26-laura horse , and set off at an actual gallop ; while [Mr. Leslie]24-leslie , who [she]0-i supposed had refused [their]1314-they invitation to join [them]1314-they , waved [his]24-leslie hand to [them]1314-they , and came alone , and slowly , along [the road in [the park]1299-the park]1316-the road in the park . Without the least hesitation . or embarrassment , [Elinor]21-elinor came forward from the trees , and caught [his]24-leslie sight , making a motion inviting [him]24-leslie to speak to [her]21-elinor . [He]24-leslie immediately rode up to the place where [she]21-elinor stood , and dismounting , eagerly told [her]21-elinor what [he]24-leslie really had done , and a great deal more which [he]24-leslie claimed to have done for [her]21-elinor . [Elinor]21-elinor was more and more troubled , and as soon as [he]24-leslie would hear [her]21-elinor , professed [her]21-elinor regret at having thus employed [him]24-leslie , in so penitent a manner , that the tears again rose to [her]21-elinor eyes , and in [his]24-leslie heart arose a tender pity , which made [him]24-leslie ready to fall down at [her]21-elinor feet , and raise [her]21-elinor by [his]24-leslie humble love above all claim and all necessity for pity . “[331-miss] [I]0-i who have been so happy to be employed by [you]332-you ! who felt it such a kindness on [your]332-you part to [a man who has [no friends]334-no friends , who wants so much a little sympathy , who would be glad to earn a kind ‘ Thank [you]332-you ’ at any sacrifice , much more by the merest commonplace service]333-a man who has no friends , who wants so much a little sympathy , who would be glad to earn a kind ‘ thank you ’ at any sacrifice , much more by the merest commonplace service . Ah , [Miss Ladylift]21-elinor ! ah , [Elinor]21-elinor ! do not talk so , do not think in this way . Who can have led [you]332-you to such thoughts ? ” “[29-miss chanson] Alas ! [Miss Chanson]29-miss chanson was very angry with [me]0-i . [She]29-miss chanson told [me]0-i [no girl in [England]6-england]335-no girl in england would be so bold , especially with [you]332-you . ” “[29-miss chanson] Did [she]29-miss chanson ; was it any consideration for [me]0-i . Did [she]29-miss chanson tell [you]332-you that it was from consideration — from any regard to [me]0-i , then ? ” “[29-miss chanson] No ! no ! [She]29-miss chanson said [she]29-miss chanson did not care for [you]332-you — it was all on [my]0-i own account . ” “[29-miss chanson] Ha ! ha ! ” said [Leslie]24-leslie , “[29-miss chanson] [she]29-miss chanson said so . Then [I]0-i think it is time for [me]0-i to go away . ” “[332-you] [You]332-you go away ! are [you]332-you then really angry with [me]0-i ? ” “[332-you] Oh ! [I]0-i beseech [you]332-you , do not say , do not think such harsh , hard words , ” said [Leslie]24-leslie , taking [her]332-you hand , and gently leading [her]332-you further into [the wood]1169-the wood . [They]1319-they walked on together side by side , deeply engaged in conversation , in which [Elinor]21-elinor ’s defencelessness touched [Leslie]24-leslie ’s heart with more of good emotion than [he]24-leslie had known could dwell there . Yet [he]24-leslie enjoyed involving [her]332-you in a situation which depended upon [himself]24-leslie to make it safe or dangerous , and which , at all events , was one in which [she]332-you compromised [herself]332-you with the prudent , and those who had more habit of [the world]1134-the world than [she]332-you . [He]24-leslie perceived [her]332-you perfect innocence of every such notion , and was every moment renewing a compact with [himself]24-leslie to hold [her]332-you in reverence . Yet [he]24-leslie secured [her]332-you hand on [his]24-leslie arm — [he]24-leslie could not keep [himself]24-leslie from touching the fingers that lay there , from gently pressing the arm which touched [his]24-leslie own . A trifling circumstance did more to check [him]24-leslie than all [his]24-leslie good resolutions . This was [his]24-leslie horse , whose bridle [he]24-leslie held , and whose uneven pace had constantly to be regulated ; sometimes it would start forward , and annoy [its master]1321-its master with a threatened invasion of [his]24-leslie toes ; sometimes stop to snatch at a bough , and when jerked on again , would shake its head , and flourish in the air in a manner dangerous to its safe keeping by the bridle . [Elinor]21-elinor ’s attention was diverted from [her]21-elinor own griefs , and [Leslie]24-leslie ’s sympathy , by the manœuvres of the horse . With the tears in [her]21-elinor eyes , [she]21-elinor was provoked to laughter at its perversity ; and when most grateful for [Leslie]24-leslie ’s assurance of friendship and support , could not help turning [their]1322-their talk to the horse ’s entertaining movements . [Leslie]24-leslie hated the animal ; and , at last , to keep the conversation in the train which pleased [him]24-leslie , [he]24-leslie invited [Elinor]21-elinor to sit down beneath a tree far and deep in [the wood]1169-the wood ; where , having fastened [his]24-leslie tiresome animal to one at a distance , [he]24-leslie returned and placed [himself]24-leslie by [her]21-elinor , distant from all the eyes that should have been guarding [her]21-elinor , and undefended by any inward consciousness of being where [she]21-elinor needed defence . “[0-i] When [I]0-i am gone , ” [he]24-leslie said , “[0-i] and go [I]0-i must , will [you]336-you think of me?—will [you]336-you remember [the friend to whom [you]336-you can always apply]337-the friend to whom you can always apply ? ” “[336-you] Yes , yes ! ” said [Elinor]21-elinor ; “[336-you] there is no danger that [I]0-i should do otherwise , for it is [you]336-you only who tell [me]0-i what [I]0-i ought to do , who show [me]0-i kindly where [I]0-i am wrong . ” “[336-you] And if [you]336-you want advice , ” said [Leslie]24-leslie — and there [he]24-leslie hesitated , whether indeed to ask [her]336-you to enter into secret correspondence with [him]24-leslie . “[336-you] [I]0-i can write to [you]336-you , if [you]336-you will tell [me]0-i [your]336-you direction , ” said [Elinor]21-elinor . “[336-you] [Divine Elinor]42-divine elinor ! ” cried [Leslie]24-leslie , carried away with delicious surprise ; and suddenly lifting the hand [he]24-leslie held to [his]24-leslie lips , [he]24-leslie kissed it fervidly , so that in astonishment [she]336-you drew it away , and a smile came for an instant over [her]336-you mouth . [Leslie]24-leslie looked down at [her]336-you with delight ; [he]24-leslie drew still nearer to [her]336-you , when the sound of rustling boughs smote [his]24-leslie ear , and then the voice of [the Squire]1324-the squire — of [Mr. Chanson]37-mr. chanson , of [[Elinor]42-divine elinor ’s guardian]1325-elinor ’s guardian — broke upon [them]1326-them . “[42-divine elinor] Hey!—what ’s this ? [You]336-you and [Miss Ladylift]21-elinor out in [the wood]1169-the wood , here?”—he was not [a man of words]1327-a man of words . [Leslie]24-leslie started up ; [Elinor]21-elinor kept [her]21-elinor seat . “[336-you] Yes ; [I]0-i came this way to enjoy the shade , and [Miss Ladylift]21-elinor had done the same . [I]0-i met with [her]21-elinor a moment ago , and was about to show [her]21-elinor the nearest way [home]139-home . ” [Elinor]21-elinor listened with wonder . [She]21-elinor thought certainly [Leslie]24-leslie had forgotten that [she]21-elinor had come to meet [him]24-leslie near [the lodge]1303-the lodge , and that [they]1326-them had spent an hour in walking to [the spot]1311-the spot together , without any reference to going [home]139-home ; however , [she]21-elinor heard [him]24-leslie as [children]1240-children hear [[their]1240-children elders]1332-their elders say things [they]1240-children have [themselves]1240-children been taught not to say , and unconsciously [they]1240-children take a lesson in the difference between learning and practising . [Mr. Chanson]37-mr. chanson asked no more ; [he]37-mr. chanson only held out [his]37-mr. chanson arm to [her]21-elinor , and said , “[0-i] Come [home]139-home with [me]0-i . [Laura]26-laura ought to have been with [you]341-you . ” [He]37-mr. chanson had a fishing‐rod in the other hand , and had been making [his]37-mr. chanson way to [the brook]1245-the brook . “[26-laura] [Miss Chanson]29-miss chanson is out riding , ” said [Elinor]21-elinor . “[29-miss chanson] And why did not [you]29-miss chanson go ? What made [you]29-miss chanson wander to [this out‐of‐the‐way place]342-this out‐of‐the‐way place ? ” [Elinor]21-elinor hesitated ; [she]21-elinor did not like to say [she]21-elinor had been scolded , and had crept away . [Mr. Chanson]37-mr. chanson thought [she]21-elinor had made an appointment with [Leslie]24-leslie , and that [her]21-elinor embarrassment came from that consciousness . “[26-laura] Well , well ! ” said [he]37-mr. chanson . “[26-laura] [Mr. Leslie]24-leslie , [you]24-leslie had better look after [your]24-leslie horse . That ’s [your]24-leslie best way [home]139-home — along [the green path]344-the green path , there . [I]0-i ’ll take [her]345-her over [the brook]1245-the brook by [the foot‐bridge]347-the foot‐bridge . Now then ! ” And [he]37-mr. chanson walked forward , [Elinor]21-elinor very willing to go with [him]37-mr. chanson , but looking back to see how [Leslie]24-leslie got up to the horse , which was drawing away , and shying at [his]37-mr. chanson approach . “[0-i] Never mind that , ” said [the Squire]1324-the squire ; “[0-i] [you]24-leslie must not be wandering about in this style . [I]0-i ’ll talk to [Laura]26-laura . ” [LESLIE]24-leslie had become aware that [his]24-leslie presence had become unacceptable to [the mistress of [the house]152-the house]1271-the mistress of the house , or rather that [his]24-leslie behaviour made it so , and therefore that it was time [he]24-leslie should go . [Her]1271-the mistress of the house evident pique , which [he]37-mr. chanson had understood from [Elinor]21-elinor ’s report of [her]21-elinor conversation with [Laura]26-laura , had confirmed this resolution , and [he]24-leslie had determined to “[0-i] have found letters at [Cantleton]7-cantleton ” which required [his]24-leslie presence elsewhere , even before [the Squire]1324-the squire looked so grim at [him]24-leslie for being alone with [Elinor]21-elinor in [the wood]1169-the wood . At dinner , therefore , [he]24-leslie avoided sitting by [Elinor]21-elinor , made [himself]24-leslie as agreeable to [Laura]26-laura as [her]26-laura anger would allow , and before [the ladies]1339-the ladies withdrew , told [her]26-laura [he]24-leslie must leave [Chan‐ son]1340-chan‐ son [Wood]43-wood next morning . [Laura]26-laura believed not one word of the story of the letters . [She]26-laura had heard [[her]26-laura brother]195-her brother ’s report , and when [he]24-leslie upbraided [her]26-laura with neglect of [her]26-laura charge , had given [him]24-leslie to understand that [the young girl]107-the young girl chose to manage [her]107-the young girl own concerns , and was amenable neither to reproof nor persuasion . [The Squire]1324-the squire had guilelessly believed [her]26-laura , inclined the more to do so by what [he]1324-the squire had [himself]1324-the squire remarked ; and [Laura]26-laura , strong in the impression [she]26-laura had then made , had courage to attempt the same thing with [Leslie]24-leslie . “[0-i] [I]0-i am sorry , ” said [she]26-laura , with a voice in which it was easy to perceive emotion , for [his]348-you departure touched the sorest place in [her]26-laura heart , “[0-i] [I]0-i am very sorry that [you]348-you have found reason to leave [us]349-us . ” “[348-you] Indeed , so am [I.]0-i [I]0-i have enjoyed the visit so much , that it is odious to [me]0-i to learn from [my]0-i letters ...... ” “[0-i] From them all ? ” said [Laura]26-laura , smiling sadly enough . “[348-you] No , no ! it ’s not [your]348-you letters . ” “[348-you] And what is it , then ? ” said [Leslie]24-leslie , abruptly , and colouring . “[348-you] Why should not [you]348-you treat [me]0-i as [a friend]350-a friend ? ” said [Laura]26-laura . “[348-you] But [I]0-i have no right to intrude on [your]348-you secrets . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i ’ve no secrets , ” said [Leslie]24-leslie , mounting higher on [his]24-leslie high horse . “[0-i] [I]0-i will not ask any , ” said [Laura]26-laura ; “[0-i] only [I]0-i can not bear to see [a friend]350-a friend [I]0-i value suffering from capricious power . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i speak in enigmas , ” said [Leslie]24-leslie . “[0-i] [I]0-i am not suffering at all , that [I]0-i know of , except in leaving [you]0-i . ” “[0-i] That ’s unkind , ” said [Laura]26-laura , suddenly , and thrown off [her]26-laura guard ; “[348-you] that ’s the last of [your]348-you thoughts . [I]0-i only wish [you]0-i were as little deceived as [you]348-you deceive [me]0-i . ” “[348-you] Deceived — deceit ! ” said [Leslie]24-leslie ’ ; “[348-you] what are [we]352-we talking about ? [I]0-i leave [two friends]353-two friends here , who are , [I]0-i know , as true as the mirror of [a mountain lake]354-a mountain lake ; [two charming ladies , whose friendship is the pride of [my]0-i life]355-two charming ladies , whose friendship is the pride of my life — [Miss Chanson]29-miss chanson and [[her]29-miss chanson ward]356-her ward , to whose joint society [I]0-i offer up all [my]0-i homage . ” [Laura]26-laura looked at [him]24-leslie steadily for a few seconds , and then changing [her]26-laura manner suddenly , uttered [her]26-laura scornful laugh , which made the blood tingle in [his]24-leslie face as though [he]24-leslie had been detected in the most egregious simplicity . “[0-i] [I]0-i doubt nothing , [I]0-i doubt [nobody]1225-nobody , ” said [he]24-leslie . “[0-i] [I]0-i am [the simplest fellow in [the world]1134-the world]358-the simplest fellow in the world . When [I]0-i see blue sky , [I]0-i believe it blue . ” “[0-i] And [the little angels]360-the little angels and all ? ” said [Laura]26-laura . “[0-i] Certainly . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i ’ll say nothing against it , then ; ” and slightly shrugging [her]26-laura shoulders , [she]26-laura escaped . When [he]24-leslie took leave of [the Squire]1324-the squire it was the same thing . “[0-i] [You]0-i are going away in a hurry , ” said [Mr. Chanson]37-mr. chanson . “[0-i] Have [you]0-i had a tiff with [anybody]262-anybody ? ” “[0-i] By no means . [I]0-i have business which obliges [me]0-i ...... ” “[0-i] Ay , ay . [They]362-they ’ll miss [you]0-i , especially [the little girl there]363-the little girl there ; but mind [you]0-i , [I]0-i know nothing about [her]363-the little girl there , beyond that [I]0-i must take care of [her]363-the little girl there . [She]363-the little girl there has not a penny , and [I]0-i am afraid is whimmy . ” [Leslie]24-leslie was vexed at [the Squire]1324-the squire ’s caution . [Laura]26-laura ’s would have been nothing , had not [[her]26-laura brother]195-her brother ’s confirmed it . There must be some‐ thing , as [both]1347-both had made a similar observation . Yet , when [he]1324-the squire met [Elinor]21-elinor before breakfast next morning , walking in [the garden]146-the garden , and [she]21-elinor told [him]1324-the squire that [she]21-elinor had hoped to see [him]1324-the squire [there]1176-there , and it was therefore [she]21-elinor had come , [he]1324-the squire forgot to ask [himself]1324-the squire if such child‐like simplicity could be feigned , and renewed all those vows of friendship and support which [Elinor]21-elinor needed ; and vowswarmer than which [he]1324-the squire felt instinctively would not be understood . [His]1324-the squire intention was to leave [her]21-elinor for a time , since [[his]1324-the squire hostess]1350-his hostess took [his]1324-the squire desertion so much amiss , but if [his]1324-the squire own heart preserved the impression [Elinor]21-elinor had made upon it , [he]1324-the squire had resolved to see [her]21-elinor again at any cost , and then to let the course of events determine [their]1351-their future relations . Accordingly [he]1324-the squire betook [himself]1324-the squire [home]139-home , where [he]1324-the squire had occupation and amusement awaiting [him]1324-the squire , and where the novelty of being [master]1353-master gave [him]1324-the squire interests which made [it]139-home the place most frequently in [his]1324-the squire thoughts when absent . [It]139-home was [an ancient house]1354-an ancient house , which seemed , from the remains of building about [it]139-home , to have been once a portion of [a much larger resi‐ dence]1355-a much larger resi‐ dence . [It]139-home stood in [a valley]1356-a valley , upon [an isolated hill]1357-an isolated hill , on the slopes of which the various ruined walls , covered for the most part with the vegetation of years , and crowned with mountain ash and birch , offered many a romantic seat , and [many a sheltered bit of terrace for whole natural beds of wild flowers]1358-many a sheltered bit of terrace for whole natural beds of wild flowers . [The house]152-the house was out of order , but not ruinous , and offered scope to the eye and fancy of [the proprietor]1360-the proprietor as to [its]152-the house restoration to [a beautiful and convenient dwelling]1361-a beautiful and convenient dwelling . From [it]152-the house one looked down [the valley]1362-the valley to [the church]1363-the church , with [its]1363-the church spire rising above [the cottages and orchards of [a village]1365-a village]1364-the cottages and orchards of a village , and on [the stream which wound its way through [wood and meadow]1367-wood and meadow]1366-the stream which wound its way through wood and meadow , wandering on towards [hills]1368-hills , for ever varying in light and shade , and as [it]1362-the valley had a western aspect , offering every evening the gorgeous spectacle of sunset . All [this valley]1369-this valley belonged to [Leslie]24-leslie , and so did [the neighbouring lands]1370-the neighbouring lands , for about 3,000 acres in all , of [poor but lovely country]1371-poor but lovely country . [He]24-leslie had a neighbour , richer than [himself]24-leslie , and with a grander place , to the east of [[his]24-leslie valley]1372-his valley ; and [a few other scattered houses]1373-a few other scattered houses , together with [a market town about six miles on , over [the common and heathy grounds]1375-the common and heathy grounds]1374-a market town about six miles on , over the common and heathy grounds , made up [[his]24-leslie neighbourhood]1376-his neighbourhood . There was plenty of game on [[Leslie]24-leslie ’s estate]1377-leslie ’s estate , and one plan for this autumn was to amuse [himself]24-leslie with its pursuit ; but though [he]24-leslie was as active as might reasonably be guessed from [his]24-leslie admirable frame , [he]24-leslie had never got up to any enthusiasm for hunting or shooting . [He]24-leslie tried the latter the first morning after [his]24-leslie return , but though the partridges were plentiful , and [his]24-leslie success considerable , [he]24-leslie thought it a more stupid occupation than ever , to‐day . While [he]24-leslie was walking over [the dry stubbles]1378-the dry stubbles , what was [Elinor]21-elinor doing ? Was [she]21-elinor reading one of those little dreamy books which [he]24-leslie had commented upon many a time , till an unwilling smile broke over [her]21-elinor lips , and [she]21-elinor turned away [her]21-elinor face that [he]24-leslie might not see it ? or was [she]21-elinor suffering from [Laura]26-laura ’s bad temper , with that pretty mournful expression in [her]21-elinor eyes and on [her]21-elinor mouth , which made [her]21-elinor look even younger than [her]21-elinor own fresh youth ? Was [she]21-elinor sitting , cool and pale , on the fallen oak in the wood , while [he]24-leslie was toiling , hot and red , in company with [[his]24-leslie gamekeeper]1379-his gamekeeper , watching a dog beguiling a bird ? [He]24-leslie went [home]139-home very early , and then walked about [[his]24-leslie own place]1381-his own place , cutting away boughs which shut out the lovely view , and projecting how to convert into an entrance [a hexagon room supported by a central pillar , which was said once to have been [a chapel]1383-a chapel]1382-a hexagon room supported by a central pillar , which was said once to have been a chapel . But [he]24-leslie was constantly leaning the hatchet idle against a tree , or drawing scrolls and scrawls on the margin of the paper where [he]24-leslie was making [his]24-leslie plans — [his]24-leslie thoughts being elsewhere , at the side of [Elinor]21-elinor , thinking over something said or done by [her]21-elinor , and what [he]24-leslie had said , or had better have said or done , in return . Two or three days made [[his]24-leslie home]1384-his home intolerable — intolerable , at least , to [a man so free to go whithersoever [his]24-leslie wishes directed [him]24-leslie]1385-a man so free to go whithersoever his wishes directed him — and getting up one morning at dawn , from a bed where [he]24-leslie could not sleep , [he]24-leslie put up a portmanteau before [[his]24-leslie servant]1386-his servant was awake , and by the time [the labourers]1387-the labourers came to [their]1387-the labourers work , was driving to [the little neighbouring town]1388-the little neighbouring town where [the coach changed horses]1389-the coach changed horses at seven o’clock . [Nobody]1225-nobody asked , and [nobody]1225-nobody knew where [he]24-leslie was going : [he]24-leslie went quite alone , and by [one change of vehicle]1392-one change of vehicle and another reached [the neighbourhood of [Chanson Wood]10-chanson wood]1393-the neighbourhood of chanson wood by nightfall . [He]24-leslie would not on any account have been recognised ; [he]24-leslie was ashamed of returning so soon , and took the most genuine precautions to remain in obscurity . [He]24-leslie engaged [a room a couple of miles from [the park]1299-the park]1394-a room a couple of miles from the park , at [a little public house where , having never entered [it]1396-a little public house where , having never entered it during his visit to the squire during [his]24-leslie visit to [the Squire]1324-the squire]1396-a little public house where , having never entered it during his visit to the squire , [he]24-leslie was unknown ; and pretending something about an engagement to survey [the country]318-the country , and displaying some paper and pencils , felt [himself]24-leslie safe from inquiry . The intense desire to see [Elinor]21-elinor again , however , would not let [him]24-leslie rest in [the house]152-the house , and as soon as the night was quite dark , [he]24-leslie took [his]24-leslie way along [the lane]1400-the lane , and through [the wicket beside [the carriage entrance]1402-the carriage entrance]1401-the wicket beside the carriage entrance , and then by cautious approaches to that side of [the house]152-the house where was [the room [the family]1405-the family occupied in the evening]1404-the room the family occupied in the evening . All was carelessly secure , as in [a great country house in the midst of [its]152-the house gardens]1406-a great country house in the midst of its gardens , and inhabited by [[its]152-the house multitude]1407-its multitude ; and [he]24-leslie had but to push open the low iron gate in the fence between [the garden]146-the garden and [the park]1299-the park , to find [himself]24-leslie upon the walk which led up beneath the windows . There was a flower border , and then a green sward , between [the house]152-the house and [the gravel walk]1411-the gravel walk , so that [Leslie]24-leslie , by walking on the turf , and then on the silent mould of the border , got noiselessly up to an open sash , and could look in and command [the whole room]1412-the whole room . All was silent inside . There were [three persons]1413-three persons , and one was [Elinor]21-elinor . [She]21-elinor was sitting beside a lamp , with [her]21-elinor face to the window , but it was leant over a piece of work which [she]21-elinor held in [her]21-elinor hands . There was nothing but white of different shades about [her]21-elinor ; [her]21-elinor muslin gown was white , a white satin bow fastened it at [her]21-elinor throat , a white lace border , or collar , lay flat on [her]21-elinor low shoulders , the work in [her]21-elinor hands was white cambric , which [she]21-elinor was embroidering ; [her]21-elinor pale face and fair hands were touched by the lamplight , and [her]21-elinor motionless figure seemed patient of [a dull employment and ungenial companions]1414-a dull employment and ungenial companions . [Laura]26-laura reclined in a chair , partly turned from the window , reading ; and [the Squire]1324-the squire was fast asleep on a sofa , breaking the silence by regular snoring , loud enough to increase [Leslie]24-leslie ’s chance of escaping detection . [He]1324-the squire saw [her]21-elinor then , [he]1324-the squire could speak to [her]21-elinor with silently moving lips , [he]1324-the squire could appeal to [her]21-elinor with passionate eyes and entreating hands , [he]1324-the squire could bend [his]1324-the squire knee towards the ground , adoring [her]21-elinor beauty , or rather [her]21-elinor loveableness . Perhaps [he]1324-the squire a little over‐wrought these gesticulations , for while most wrapped in them , a little dog , which was lying with its back well into [Laura]26-laura ’s silk gown , jumped up , and gave a sharp volley of barks . [Elinor]21-elinor looked suddenly up , but [Leslie]24-leslie was gone into the shadow . [The Squire]1324-the squire did not cease [his]1324-the squire sonorous aspirations , and [Laura]26-laura was too much used to [her]26-laura [Spitz]44-spitz ’s hysterical alarms to move so much as [her]26-laura head . But [Leslie]24-leslie felt [his]24-leslie security gone ; and that probably [the little Spitz]44-spitz ’s eyes were even then on the window , beaming with the purpose of another frantic yap upon the smallest sign from outside . [He]1324-the squire withdrew very cautiously , but [his]1324-the squire soul was bitter against [the Spitz]44-spitz . “[363-the little girl there] Let [me]0-i catch [you]364-you outside these walls , [Master Puff]45-master puff , and see if [you]364-you disturb [me]0-i again , ” murmured [he]1324-the squire , as [he]1324-the squire retreated . The necessity of [his]1324-the squire soul was to see [Elinor]21-elinor again ; [he]1324-the squire wished to be the unseen spectator of what [she]21-elinor was and did , to make sure that [a creature so innocent really existed , and to enjoy the spectacle if it was true]1417-a creature so innocent really existed , and to enjoy the spectacle if it was true . To enjoy it and destroy it ; for [he]1324-the squire looked no further than to present gratification of the passion which filled [his]1324-the squire breast — all [his]1324-the squire remoter thoughts were of ambition and success in the tempestuous world , which seemed another sphere from that [he]1324-the squire occupied at present . [He]1324-the squire put on , next day , the dress of [a workman]1418-a workman , and as deeply slouched a hat as [he]1324-the squire could suppose consistent with the character . [He]1324-the squire provided [himself]1324-the squire with an axe , and hoped to pass unrecognised , if [he]1324-the squire could avoid direct communication with [[his]1324-the squire former host]1419-his former host and [fellow guests]1420-fellow guests ; and taking [his]1324-the squire way into [the woods]1421-the woods about [the house]152-the house , went first to [the brook]1245-the brook , where [he]1324-the squire had shown [Elinor]21-elinor [the waterfall]286-the waterfall , and where [he]1324-the squire knew [she]21-elinor had occasionally resorted after that time . [His]1324-the squire expectations were more than fulfilled , for [he]1324-the squire had no pains of waiting to go through , no fears , no doubtful hopes ; a figure was standing on [the very spot whither [he]1324-the squire had led [Elinor]21-elinor]1425-the very spot whither he had led elinor , and though the face was turned away , the elegant shape was that which [he]1324-the squire longed to see . The falling water prevented [his]1324-the squire step from being heard , and [he]1324-the squire was able to take up a place among [the trees]1426-the trees , where [he]1324-the squire could observe [her]21-elinor , yet run scarce any danger of detection . Should [she]21-elinor perceive [him]1324-the squire , [he]1324-the squire would deal a few strokes at the trees , and trust to be taken for [the forester]1427-the forester , and pass unnoticed . The unconscious [Elinor]21-elinor made [her]21-elinor preparations for passing the burning hours in shade and a refreshing atmosphere . [She]21-elinor laid aside [her]21-elinor bonnet , put by [her]21-elinor gloves , unfastened the cotton gown from [her]21-elinor throat , and it charmed [him]1324-the squire to see [she]21-elinor did not open a book , but unfolded a piece of household work , and industriously shaped , and hemmed , and sewed at the white jacket [she]21-elinor was making . Sometimes [she]21-elinor paused , and looked long at the lovely fall of waters , and once going down to the edge of [the brook]1245-the brook , took water in [her]21-elinor joined hands , and drank from that pretty cup . Then returning , [she]21-elinor resumed [her]21-elinor work , and gave no sign of thoughts within , except a few times singing some notes , like a bird alone in the sun , trying a passage taught by the impulse of its melodious throat . It was a fair picture of still life , and [he]1324-the squire looked at it with the passion of [a lover]1429-a lover , and the eye of [an artist]1430-an artist ; but at last [he]1324-the squire began to grow discontented that there was no sign of wanting or thinking of [him]1324-the squire , no looks cast upwards , no sighs , no restless movement , which [he]1324-the squire might have interpreted into regret that [he]1324-the squire was not there . Should [he]1324-the squire suddenly appear , would [he]1324-the squire be welcome even ? Yes , welcome , perhaps , as a novelty , not as the thing desired — welcome to come and go , but if [she]21-elinor knew [he]1324-the squire had come all that way merely to look at [her]21-elinor , [she]21-elinor would laugh . [He]1324-the squire was [a very young man]1431-a very young man , and little knew the patience of [a modest maiden]1432-a modest maiden , nor the absence of all spoken words , and speaking signs , when [she]1432-a modest maiden is with [herself]1432-a modest maiden alone , and is occupied with [her]1432-a modest maiden natural duties and works . [He]1324-the squire watched [her]21-elinor all that morning , and saw [her]21-elinor at last fold [her]21-elinor work , rise and gather some beech leaves while [she]21-elinor stood under the tree , to wind one into the other , till they made a wreath , then hanging it on [her]21-elinor wrist , [she]21-elinor took up [her]21-elinor wicker basket , and shortly withdrew towards [the house]152-the house . “[364-you] Dear household [Lar]46-lar , ” said [he]1324-the squire , coming and standing exactly in front of the seat [she]21-elinor had occupied , “[46-lar] one day [you]46-lar will sit beside some humble hearth , content to do the lowly offices of [home]139-home , to live the joyless life of little wants and coarse means ; [your]46-lar fragile loveliness will be stained by weather and hard work , [your]46-lar pure voice will have lost its clearness , but neither [you]46-lar nor [yours]46-lar will think it worsened since these days . [I]0-i should not love [you]46-lar then — [I]0-i shall be in [my]0-i grave , or on the summit of ambition then — but there is an interval between that time and this , in which , oh ! [Elinor]21-elinor ! [your]46-lar quiet heart must beat — beat as [mine]0-i does now — in which [you]46-lar must know the agony of [my]0-i adoration — in which [we]366-we must make life all diamond‐light , if it be but for the space of a moon ’s change ! Ex‐ quisite calm face , when will [you]46-lar lighten thus for [me]0-i ? ” Next day , [he]1324-the squire came again , and saw [her]21-elinor again . It was , as the village bells told [him]1324-the squire , a Saint ’s day , and [Elinor]21-elinor , whom [no one]1434-no one helped to perform [her]21-elinor usual devotions in an appointed place , came into [the entangled woods]1435-the entangled woods to find [a temple]1436-a temple . [He]1324-the squire saw [her]21-elinor kneel in front of the great tree , and with humble eyes cast upon the ground , sign the cross upon [her]21-elinor bosom , and open [her]21-elinor little book of prayer . Even in these devotions there was something which suited [his]1324-the squire feeling about [Elinor]21-elinor better than if the prayer had been more untaught , more [her]21-elinor own creation . [She]21-elinor passively did what [she]21-elinor had been taught to do — [she]21-elinor murmured over a form of words , continually coming to the same repetition , and making the same sign of devotion . [She]21-elinor turned [her]21-elinor pages to the places where marks in the book showed [she]21-elinor ought to go , and though the service lasted long , showed no wish either to shorten or prolong it , but did what was set down for [her]21-elinor , and then rose and had done . Again [she]21-elinor took [her]21-elinor seat upon [the fallen tree]1437-the fallen tree , again unfolded [her]21-elinor work , and again , with the shadows of boughs and leaves moving over [her]21-elinor as the breath of air gently swayed them , sat plying [her]21-elinor household needle . What thoughts broke in upon the even train which was necessary to guide that needle , [he]1324-the squire would fain have guessed . Surely some thoughts must accompany the motion of those active fingers — perhaps there were many given to convent days ; perhaps some to [him]1324-the squire — [he]1324-the squire wished it , but hardly hoped it ; but at last , without the sewing being interrupted , [he]1324-the squire heard well known notes begin to murmur from [her]21-elinor throat , and go on to a continued but still low song , which made [him]1324-the squire believe those tranquil thoughts had indeed been recalling [him]1324-the squire , and had come to the point which made that song and [him]1324-the squire one common subject , for it was the air of a duett in which [he]1324-the squire had attempted to join [her]21-elinor , an air sung at [village weddings in [Brittany]2-brittany]1438-village weddings in brittany , and [he]1324-the squire had never seen [her]21-elinor laugh so cordially as at [his]1324-the squire failures in trying to keep a second . Now [he]1324-the squire heard the village notes and verses again , and believed [his]1324-the squire own image was before [her]21-elinor . [She]21-elinor broke off before the verse was finished , and [he]1324-the squire saw [her]21-elinor look from [her]21-elinor work , and though [he]1324-the squire could not hear it , was certain [she]21-elinor laughed — briefly , as one does alone . Then there was some measuring or adapting in the work , which took up [her]21-elinor attention , and obliged [her]21-elinor to rise and use the fallen tree for a table , and when all was in order , [she]21-elinor again sat down to work , and seemed to have forgotten all about “[46-lar] vot’e mariage . ” Probably they were the words in the song which were the very last [she]21-elinor thought about . The intense pleasure of watching , and appropriating [her]21-elinor solitary ways and movements , had gone on long past mid‐day , when [Leslie]24-leslie heard a step coming along [the rough track]1439-the rough track which led from [the wood walk]1440-the wood walk to [this unfrequented place]1441-this unfrequented place . It was only [a servant]1442-a servant , who , approaching [Elinor]21-elinor , delivered some message and went away again ; and [she]21-elinor , in consequence it seemed , collected the materials of [her]21-elinor employment , and left [her]21-elinor seat probably to obey a summons to [the house]152-the house . [Leslie]24-leslie was vexed , first at losing [his]24-leslie amusement , and next at the way in which it was lost . “[367-he] [I]0-i thought [he]367-he had chosen [a spot all unknown]368-a spot all unknown , ” said [he]24-leslie , to himself—“one[367-he] which [a lover]1429-a lover only could discover — but it seems [the very servants]370-the very servants know where [she]1429-a lover is to be found , much more [every idle puppy and loiterer belonging to the society”—puppy [himself]24-leslie]1444-every idle puppy and loiterer belonging to the society”—puppy himself , though of [a stout , handsome breed]1445-a stout , handsome breed . However , there was no probability of [her]1429-a lover return , [he]24-leslie thought , and after half an hour ’s waiting for the chance of it , [he]24-leslie had moved away , and was descending towards [the brook]1245-the brook , when [he]24-leslie perceived a motion in the boughs overhanging the path , and stopping to watch , perceived it was [Elinor]21-elinor coming again , and in haste , to the accustomed spot . [Leslie]24-leslie was in front of [her]1429-a lover , and accident gave [him]24-leslie a better place to see [her]1429-a lover than [he]24-leslie had ventured to choose for [himself]24-leslie ; [his]24-leslie fear was that [she]1429-a lover should also perceive [him]24-leslie , but [she]1429-a lover evidently was in a mood so preoccupied as not readily to have [her]1429-a lover attention caught by outer objects . All [her]1429-a lover humble tranquillity was gone . As soon as [she]1429-a lover reached [her]1429-a lover fallen tree , [she]1429-a lover sank down upon it , and leaning both hands upon one of the projecting branches , hid [her]1429-a lover face , and wept bitterly . [She]1429-a lover lifted [her]1429-a lover head more than once , to wipe [her]1429-a lover streaming eyes , and then hid them again , as though the lovely scene were blotted and rendered null by the grief within . Presently [she]1429-a lover rose , and went hastily down to [the brook]1245-the brook , and there kneeling and stooping over it , dashed the water repeatedly over [her]1429-a lover face , and let [her]1429-a lover hair come dripping from [the stream]1448-the stream . [She]1429-a lover then sat down on a rock close to the margin , and not five yards from [Leslie]24-leslie , but , as it chanced , with [her]1429-a lover back to [him]24-leslie , and bringing from a little basket a case containing paper and a pen , [she]1429-a lover put [her]1429-a lover lithe figure into such a position as to find a desk on part of the rock where [she]1429-a lover sat , and began hastily to write . [Leslie]24-leslie ’s heart beat faster than ever . Had [she]1429-a lover not asked [him]24-leslie for [his]24-leslie direction , that [she]1429-a lover might apply to [him]24-leslie if ever [she]1429-a lover was in trouble ? Was [she]1429-a lover writing to [him]24-leslie ? To whom else was it probable , that in that sudden grief , whatever it might be , [she]1429-a lover should be writing ? and [he]24-leslie so near — [he]24-leslie could almost see the lines as [she]1429-a lover traced them . Did [she]1429-a lover summon [him]24-leslie to [her]1429-a lover ? What would [she]1429-a lover say if [he]24-leslie were suddenly at [her]1429-a lover side?—but then [he]24-leslie should lose all the gratitude due to obeying [her]1429-a lover call — [he]24-leslie should be [the inferior who had come to seek]1449-the inferior who had come to seek , instead of [the superior who had been besought to come]1450-the superior who had been besought to come . No , [he]24-leslie would not hazard that!—besides , [he]24-leslie was not sure that [she]1429-a lover was writing to [him]24-leslie ; it might be [some one else to whom [she]1429-a lover was appealing]1451-some one else to whom she was appealing . [She]1429-a lover had very suddenly made [him]24-leslie [[her]1429-a lover confidant]1452-her confidant — it was not impossible that there might be [others equally favoured]1453-others equally favoured . What was it [the Squire]1324-the squire had said [she]1429-a lover was — whimmy?—he had called [her]1429-a lover whimmy . Yet , alas ! that [she]1429-a lover should cry so , and [no one]1434-no one be near to comfort [her]1429-a lover . Would not [she]1429-a lover cling to [him]24-leslie like [a friend]350-a friend if [she]1429-a lover saw [him]24-leslie ? would not [she]1429-a lover be gladder than [she]1429-a lover knew ? Yet , possibly , [no!—he]47-no!—he would not hazard it — but that letter [he]24-leslie would get by some means , and it should not be long before it was [his]24-leslie ; then [he]24-leslie should know what to do . Meantime , [Elinor]21-elinor finished the hastily‐written letter , folded it , and replacing the little matters in [her]21-elinor basket , pushed the basket among the ferns and stones , and hastily took [her]21-elinor way by a difficult path down [the dingle]1457-the dingle . [Leslie]24-leslie concluded that [she]21-elinor was going to the post‐office to put in [her]21-elinor letter ; and [he]24-leslie purposed to follow soon after , and ask for it in [his]24-leslie own name , in case it should be addressed to [him]24-leslie . But then the letter would be directed to [[his]24-leslie own place]1381-his own place , of which [he]24-leslie had given [Elinor]21-elinor the direction , and at the post‐office [they]1459-they would not dare give it except where it was addressed . Yet [he]24-leslie knew [the old woman]1308-the old woman who acted as [post‐mistress]1461-post‐mistress , and [she]1308-the old woman had been constantly in the habit of seeing [him]24-leslie during [his]24-leslie visit at [[Mr. Chanson]37-mr. chanson ’s]1462-mr. chanson ’s , and perhaps , if [he]24-leslie resumed the clothes and character of [Mr. Leslie]24-leslie , [she]1308-the old woman might be prevailed upon to disregard the direction in favour of the bodily presence of [the man directed to]1463-the man directed to . [He]24-leslie therefore rushed back to [[his]24-leslie lodgings]1464-his lodgings to change [[his]24-leslie peasant]1465-his peasant ’s dress , and then , regardless of being discovered , regardless of everything except the possession of the letter , [he]24-leslie turned back boldly to the post‐office . For the convenience of [the great house]1466-the great house , it was located at [the park gates]1467-the park gates , in [the lodge]1303-the lodge , and was kept by [the same old woman who had taken notice of [Elinor]21-elinor ’s watch for [Mr. Leslie]24-leslie]1469-the same old woman who had taken notice of elinor ’s watch for mr. leslie . [She]1308-the old woman was perfectly familiar with [his]24-leslie appearance , but when [he]24-leslie went into [the house]152-the house and inquired if there was anything for [him]24-leslie , [she]1308-the old woman started as if [she]1308-the old woman had no expectation nor wish to see [him]24-leslie , and seemed to take the circumstance occurring as a personal injury . “[370-the very servants] A letter for [P. Leslie]48-p. leslie , Esq . ? ” said [she]1308-the old woman ; “[48-p. leslie] there ’s more fuss than enough about [P. Leslie]48-p. leslie , [Esq]49-esq . [I]0-i ca n’t sit to [my]0-i tea for [people]272-people all coming for that blessed letter . ” “[0-i] Then there is one , ” cried [Leslie]24-leslie , eagerly , “[0-i] give it . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i did not say there was , ” said [the old woman]1308-the old woman ; “[0-i] and if there should be , it ’s gone away in the west bag as directed . ” “[0-i] Gone ! ” cried [he]24-leslie , stamping impatiently ; “[0-i] what luck [I]0-i have ! but when — there ’s been no mail since — when did it go , [I]0-i say ? ” “[0-i] The mail was due at eleven and half , ” said [the post‐mistress]1472-the post‐mistress , “[0-i] but it might be ten minutes later . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i are not telling [me]0-i the truth , ” said [Leslie]24-leslie ; “[0-i] the letter was not here then . ” “[0-i] If [you]0-i know better than [I]0-i , [sir]372-sir , then [I]0-i say no more . ” “[0-i] Nay ! ” said [Leslie]24-leslie ; “[0-i] but [you]0-i know [you]0-i were telling stories — and what ’s the use ? The letter is here , and [you]0-i may as well get half a guinea by giving it [me]0-i as not . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i ca n’t do no such thing ; it ’s made up in the bag to go where it ought to go , and [I]0-i ’m forbidden by [[my]0-i office]373-my office to let [anybody]262-anybody meddle with it , except [the right person]375-the right person at the right place . ” “[375-the right person] But , ” said [Leslie]24-leslie , “[0-i] [you]0-i have already let [somebody]376-somebody meddle ; [the person]377-the person — [the people]378-the people — who [you]0-i say have been disturbing [you]0-i at [your]0-i tea . ” [The old woman]1308-the old woman coloured up to the eyes , though [she]1308-the old woman would not give way . “[0-i] [I]0-i said [somebody]376-somebody disturbed [me]0-i ; and so [she]376-somebody did . Was not the hole cut away in the window for letters to be dropped in ? Where ’s the use of bringing them into [the house]152-the house , and not being content with the natural gap . ” “[0-i] That ’s not what [you]0-i meant by disturbing [you]0-i , ” said [Leslie]24-leslie ; “[0-i] [that person]381-that person may have brought the letter into [the house]152-the house , but after it was in the box , [I]0-i believe [you]0-i have been taking it out for [somebody else]383-somebody else , and [you]0-i ca n’t produce it for [the right owner]384-the right owner . ” “[0-i] Ca n’t [I]0-i ? ” said [the old woman]1308-the old woman . “[0-i] No ! [I]0-i shall inform against [you]0-i , ” said . [Leslie]24-leslie , “[0-i] for allowing [[your]0-i office]385-your office to be tampered with , unless [you]0-i immediately put it into [my]0-i possession . ” “[0-i] That will just be doing the thing [you]0-i are going to complain of , ” said [the old woman]1308-the old woman . [Leslie]24-leslie was provoked to smile . “Come[0-i] , come , ” said [he]24-leslie , “[0-i] [I]0-i will have the letter , and [you]0-i may as well take [my]0-i money at once , for the trouble of opening [your]0-i bags , although [I]0-i know they are not shut . Here , [old lady]386-old lady , do n’t tell any more lies , but do as [you]0-i are bid . ” [The ancient post‐mistress]1476-the ancient post‐mistress laughed , and went to the box into which the letters were dropped . [Leslie]24-leslie found out [her]0-i fibs as fast as [she]0-i composed them , and [she]0-i acknowledged [him]24-leslie a master spirit . A little rummaging and a little grumbling produced the letter in question , and [Leslie]24-leslie seizing it , first of all before devouring the contents , carefully examined the folds and fastening , for [he]24-leslie had conceived certain suspicions from [the old lady]1477-the old lady ’s words . “[0-i] Who opened this letter ? ” said [he]24-leslie , abruptly , after looking at it attentively . “[0-i] [Nobody]1225-nobody but [yourself]0-i , ” said [she]0-i , trying to lay [her]0-i thumb on the fastening ; “[0-i] [you]0-i have worried it in turning it about so . ” “[0-i] No , no ! ” said [Leslie]24-leslie , guarding it from [her]0-i , for though [he]24-leslie had only asked the question as a random shot , [he]24-leslie now was certain that there was some mystery . “[0-i] That [I]0-i have not , neither shall [you]0-i ; but [you]0-i shall tell [me]0-i what [I]0-i ask , for [I]0-i have [you]0-i in [my]0-i power , and [I]0-i will know . ” [The old sharpshooter]1478-the old sharpshooter was chased from [her]1478-the old sharpshooter defences , but ran and took up another position . “[0-i] Well — well , ” said [she]0-i , “[0-i] [you]0-i are [a young gentleman]388-a young gentleman , and [a mighty good‐looking]389-a mighty good‐looking , and if [I]0-i were [you]0-i , [I]0-i should not take it amiss that [the ladies]1339-the ladies thought worth while escorting [my]0-i letters , and jealousing what was writ in them . It is not [old gentlemen]391-old gentlemen and [old ladies]392-old ladies as do such things . ” “[29-miss chanson] In short , [Miss Chanson]29-miss chanson has had this letter in [her]29-miss chanson hands before [me]0-i . ” “[29-miss chanson] Oh ! [dear me!—Miss Chanson!—no]393-dear me!—miss chanson!—no , [dear no!—I]394-dear no!—i never said no such thing . ” “[394-dear no!—i] No , [you]394-dear no!—i did not say it ! ” said [Leslie]24-leslie . “[394-dear no!—i] [I]0-i perfectly comprehend that it could not possibly be [that lady]395-that lady ; and now do n’t be afraid , for [I]0-i know all [I]0-i want . Good evening . ” “[396-a wilful man] That ’s [a wilful man]396-a wilful man , ” said [the post‐mistress]1472-the post‐mistress to [herself]1472-the post‐mistress , “[396-a wilful man] and those be [two silly girls]397-two silly girls to have anything to do with [him]396-a wilful man . ” [Leslie]24-leslie meantime walked hastily away , and took a path over [the fields]1480-the fields to be out of observation , opening and reading the much canvassed letter as [he]24-leslie went along . [He]24-leslie could not but smile at the simplicity of [the writer]1481-the writer ’s alarms , and of [her]1472-the post‐mistress confidence in [him]24-leslie . “[397-two silly girls] [Sir]372-sir , ( ” that ’s [Monsieur]1482-monsieur , “[396-a wilful man] said [he]396-a wilful man ) — ” [SIR]372-sir — [You]372-sir are [[my]372-sir only friend]1484-my only friend ; [I]372-sir do not know what to do unless [you]372-sir can help [me]372-sir — and [you]372-sir told [me]372-sir to ask [you]372-sir for help if [I]372-sir was in trouble . Have [you]372-sir money [you]372-sir can lend [me]372-sir ? [I]372-sir will pay [you]372-sir back , a little every quarter , and once [you]372-sir said it was not wrong to borrow from [you]372-sir . [Miss Chanson]29-miss chanson called [me]372-sir , and gave [me]372-sir many bills , which [I]372-sir did not know of — perhaps [they]399-they will put [me]372-sir in [prison]1485-prison . What will become of [me]372-sir ? “[372-sir] [ELINOR LADYLIFT]21-elinor . ” “[21-elinor] Poor , precious , enchanting [Elinor]21-elinor ! ” cried [he]372-sir ; “[21-elinor] how unkind , how sententious , [they]399-they are to [you]21-elinor . [I]0-i can see the matter from here ; ordinary bills are thrust into [your]21-elinor hands , without explanation , without advice , and [your]21-elinor conventual imagination sees nothing in them but [an ogre of a creditor]400-an ogre of a creditor , and dungeons and chains . Oh ! how can [I]0-i be soonest with [you]21-elinor ? [I]0-i dare not come at once , for even [your]21-elinor innocence would disbelieve that [I]0-i was as far off as [I]0-i ought to have been when [I]0-i got [your]21-elinor summons . Yet — summons ! no , it is not that ; nothing was further , [I]0-i do believe , from [your]21-elinor thoughts , than to call [me]0-i to [you]21-elinor — yet , poor dove , [you]21-elinor have done so , and when such fair birds are no better looked after by [[their]399-they natural guardians]401-their natural guardians , what is indeed to become of [them]399-they ? Now [I]0-i must write so as not to frighten [her]402-her . ” Accordingly [he]403-he wrote in the soberest manner , making much , indeed , of [her]402-her embarrassments , but promising to alleviate them ; and then informed [her]402-her “[402-her] that particular circumstances having called [him]403-he into [[her]402-her neighbourhood]404-her neighbourhood , [he]403-he had received [her]402-her letter in a most fortunately brief space of time , and [he]403-he should be able , that very evening , to meet [her]402-her near [the waterfall]286-the waterfall in [the wood]1169-the wood , and to bring [her]402-her the means of extricating [herself]402-her from [her]402-her difficulties . ” “[402-her] [She]402-her will wonder why [I]0-i should not walk straight up to [the house]152-the house , and ask to see [Miss Ladylift]21-elinor , ” said [he]403-he , as [he]403-he sealed [his]403-he letter ; “[21-elinor] but [I]0-i hope the spirit of intrigue and coquetry may awaken in [her]402-her sufficiently to do as [I]0-i suggest , and ask no questions . ” The next difficulty was to convey this letter to [her]402-her , and it perplexed [him]403-he till [he]403-he saw [the Squire]1324-the squire and [Laura]26-laura ride past [[his]403-he lodging]1487-his lodging , and thus knew [they]1488-they were out of the way ; and then [he]403-he resolved to go [himself]403-he to [the house]152-the house , in [the peasant]1490-the peasant ’s dress [he]403-he had worn in the morning , and there to put [his]403-he answer into the hands of [a labouring clod]1491-a labouring clod in [the gardens]1492-the gardens . This [he]403-he did , begging [him]1491-a labouring clod to take “[50-mr. davis tailior] [Mr. Davis tailior]50-mr. davis tailior ’s acquoint for [the French lady]408-the french lady , up speedy to [the house]152-the house . ” [The obliging clod]1493-the obliging clod complied , and [Leslie]24-leslie returned to [[his]403-he lodging]1487-his lodging , and early in the evening to [the woods]1421-the woods , expecting the guileless creature who put such confidence in [him]403-he . Nor was [he]403-he disappointed . About nine o’clock , of a warm , moonlit , September evening , [Leslie]24-leslie standing anxiously in [the wood‐path]1496-the wood‐path , saw [Elinor]21-elinor coming along [it]1496-the wood‐path to meet [him]410-you . “[50-mr. davis tailior] How good [you]410-you are , ” [she]0-i said , as [they]1497-they met ; “[410-you] but indeed [I]0-i did not mean to trouble [you]410-you thus . [I]0-i thought [you]410-you would have written to [me]0-i ; indeed , [I]0-i did not think of [your]410-you coming . ” “[0-i] But [you]0-i are not displeased ? ” said [Leslie]24-leslie , taking [her]0-i hand , which [she]0-i withdrew when [she]0-i had performed the proper greeting . “[0-i] For [my]0-i part , [I]0-i am so happy to be of any service to [you]410-you , [I]0-i am so happy to see [you]410-you again , that [I]0-i can not but bless the difficulties which have brought this meeting about . ” “[24-leslie] Oh ! [Mr. Leslie]24-leslie , [I]0-i am sure [you]24-leslie would not say so , if [you]24-leslie knew how miserable [I]0-i have been . ” “[24-leslie] But [you]0-i are miserable no longer , are [you]0-i ? ” said [Leslie]24-leslie ; “[0-i] [you]0-i feel that [I]0-i am able and willing to remove every cause of pain — [I]0-i am able to make [you]0-i happy . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i hope so , ” said [Elinor]21-elinor ; “[0-i] but it will be a long time before [I]0-i can pay [you]24-leslie . ” “[0-i] What ! pay [me]0-i ? Oh ! [I]0-i was not thinking of that ; [I]0-i was thinking , ” said [Leslie]24-leslie , drawing [her]21-elinor gently to the fallen tree , where [he]24-leslie had watched [her]21-elinor sitting those autumn days , and placing [himself]24-leslie beside [her—“I]0-i[0-i] was thinking whether [you]0-i did not know that [I]0-i look upon this moment , when [you]0-i trust [me]0-i , when [I]0-i [you]0-i apply to [me]0-i , when [you]0-i know [me]0-i to be [a better friend than [any of those whom chance has thrown [you]0-i amongst]412-any of those whom chance has thrown you amongst , as the most delightful that ever in all [my]0-i youth and enjoyment passed over [me”—he]0-i possessed [himself]0-i of [her]0-i hand—“and[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t deceive [myself]0-i , do [I]0-i ? [You]0-i know [me]0-i to be [[your]0-i truest well‐wisher]413-your truest well‐wisher , [[your]0-i most anxious counsellor]414-your most anxious counsellor]411-a better friend than any of those whom chance has thrown you amongst , as the most delightful that ever in all my youth and enjoyment passed over me”—he possessed himself of her hand—“and i do n’t deceive myself , do i ? you know me to be your truest well‐wisher , your most anxious counsellor , [the person who would desire [your]0-i happiness beyond all other things , and do whatever may best promote it]415-the person who would desire your happiness beyond all other things , and do whatever may best promote it . ” [Elinor]21-elinor ’s hand stayed in [his]1498-his , but it was with the calmest voice [she]0-i answered , “[0-i] Yes , or [you]0-i would not be here to help [me]0-i . ” “[0-i] No , no ! and [you]0-i felt it was [none of [those guardians of [yours]0-i]417-those guardians of yours , who was willing to do so?—you did not apply to [them]417-those guardians of yours]416-none of those guardians of yours , who was willing to do so?—you did not apply to them ? ” “[0-i] Oh ! [I]0-i should never have done such a thing , ” said [Elinor]21-elinor , the slightest smile passing over [her]0-i face , as at the suggestion of something wholly out of the question . “[0-i] [I]0-i have a kind of right , [you]0-i have given [me]0-i a right to counsel [you]0-i , guard [you]0-i ; [you]0-i are inclined to do as [I]0-i advise [you]0-i ? ” “[0-i] Yes , ” said [Elinor]21-elinor , with a mournful inflection in [her]21-elinor voice . “[0-i] [I]0-i know nothing at all of [this world]418-this world [I]0-i am in , and [I]0-i have found [you]0-i wise , knowing everything . [You]0-i can teach [me]0-i what [you]0-i please , but [I]0-i know [you]0-i will teach [me]0-i what is right . ” “[0-i] Ah , yes ! right — the right way to be happy — and [we]419-our are [creatures made to be happy]420-creatures made to be happy , not to suffer pain from each , [other]421-other , not to be unkindly treated , but to seek out those who love [us]419-our , and to put all [our]419-our trust that what [they]422-they do will be the best [they]422-they know how to do , for [our]419-our happiness . ” [Elinor]21-elinor was silent . [She]21-elinor was listening , and trying to comprehend . “[21-elinor] [Elinor]21-elinor , did any ever devote [themselves]423-themselves to [you]21-elinor , and think , of nothing except how to please , how to take care of [you]21-elinor ; what [you]21-elinor liked , where [you]21-elinor would go ? ” “[424-your kind mother in the convent] Oh ! no , certainly , ” said [Elinor]21-elinor . “[424-your kind mother in the convent] [[Your]21-elinor kind Mother in [the Convent]127-the convent]424-your kind mother in the convent , [[your]21-elinor teachers]426-your teachers [the nuns]427-the nuns , [[your]21-elinor companions]428-your companions — did [you]21-elinor ever feel that when [you]21-elinor came [they]429-they rejoiced , when [you]21-elinor went [they]429-they mourned ; that [you]21-elinor were the thing [they]429-they first thought of at waking ; the object for which [they]429-they planned [their]429-they plans , lamented [their]429-they failures ? ” “[430-he] No ! ” said [Elinor]21-elinor , “[429-they] [they]429-they were not so unreasonable . ” “[429-they] But [he]430-he who loves [you]21-elinor is so unreasonable , so reasonable at the same time , for that which is dearer than [oneself]431-oneself must be more present , more cherished than [oneself]431-oneself — the happiness of that creature must be before every other wish and plan . Would it be no pleasure , dearest [Elinor]21-elinor , to be thus beloved ? ” [His]430-he right hand suddenly transferred [her]21-elinor ’s to [his]430-he left , and went round [her]21-elinor waist , nor did it fail to press that slender , warm column , which it had encircled . [Elinor]21-elinor did not withdraw , but [she]21-elinor raised [her]21-elinor clear eyes to [his]430-he , and met [his]430-he fierce glance with such inquiring , innocent calmness , that [his]430-he arm released its hold , and [he]430-he did but raise [her]21-elinor hand to [his]430-he mouth , and pressed one kiss upon it . “[21-elinor] May [I]0-i not love [you]21-elinor , [Elinor]21-elinor ? ” “[0-i] Indeed [I]0-i think [you]0-i do , ” said [Elinor]21-elinor . “[0-i] [I]0-i doubt whether [you]21-elinor do as much for [me]0-i , ” said [Leslie]24-leslie , to [himself]0-i , and [he]430-he felt that [he]430-he should but set [her]21-elinor on [her]21-elinor guard by any further revelation of [his]430-he feelings ; but [he]430-he was not wholly displeased with the step [he]430-he had advanced . All recollection of the cause of [their]1499-their meeting had departed from [him]430-he ; but while [he]430-he was thinking how best to go on with the interview , [Elinor]21-elinor took advantage of the pause , and returned to the difficulties [he]430-he was to settle for [her]21-elinor , which to [him]430-he appeared prosaic and superfluous , but to [her]21-elinor was the thing that made [their]1499-their meeting interesting . [Leslie]24-leslie took from [her]21-elinor hand the little neat bundle of papers which [she]21-elinor produced ; [he]430-he comprehended that [Laura]26-laura had not chosen to explain or soften anything , and promised that [he]430-he would [himself]430-he arrange all . [He]430-he would then have passed to [other subjects]1500-other subjects , but [Elinor]21-elinor would stay no longer after [she]21-elinor had fulfilled [her]21-elinor errand , and then [he]430-he fixed the next afternoon for another meeting at [the same place]1501-the same place , to give account of what [he]430-he should have done . “[21-elinor] Say nothing of [our]432-our meeting , ” said [he]430-he ; “[21-elinor] it is best not . [I]0-i can scarcely explain why ; but promise that [you]433-you will follow [my]0-i advice . ” [Elinor]21-elinor did so . [She]21-elinor had no conscience but [Leslie]24-leslie — [her]21-elinor own had never come much into activity , and that which [she]21-elinor brought from [the Convent]127-the convent had been all overthrown . [Elinor]21-elinor returned to [the house]152-the house , and to [the saloon where [Mr. Chanson]37-mr. chanson and [[his]37-mr. chanson sister [Laura]26-laura]1505-his sister laura]1504-the saloon where mr. chanson and his sister laura were sitting , and entering [it]1504-the saloon where mr. chanson and his sister laura with [her]21-elinor light , noiseless movement , was taking up [her]21-elinor work , and about to seat [herself]21-elinor in [her]21-elinor usual place , when [Laura]26-laura stopped [her]21-elinor , by asking , in a constrained voice , “[433-you] Where have [you]434-you been , [Elinor]21-elinor ? ” “[434-you] In [the wood]1169-the wood , ” said [Elinor]21-elinor , the colour rising , [she]21-elinor knew not why . “[434-you] But , [[my]0-i dear]1127-my dear , ” said [the Squire]1324-the squire , “[434-you] that ’s not the proper place for [a young girl like [you]434-you]437-a young girl like you , at night , all alone ; [you]434-you should not go there . ” “[434-you] And were [you]434-you alone ? ” said [Laura]26-laura , briefly . [Elinor]21-elinor had nothing to say ; the question was so home , that it admitted but of yes or no ; one of which [she]21-elinor might not , and the other [she]21-elinor would not say . “[434-you] Speak out , ” said [Mr. Chanson]37-mr. chanson ; “[434-you] do n’t be afraid of [us]438-us . Tell the truth always . ” “[0-i] Oh , yes ! that [I]0-i will , always , ” said [Elinor]21-elinor . “[0-i] [You]434-you were alone , then , [I]0-i dare say , were [you]434-you not ? ” said [Mr. Chanson]37-mr. chanson . “[0-i] Still [I]0-i do n’t like [you]434-you to wander about alone , and [you]434-you will do it no more , will [you]434-you ? ” “[434-you] Very well , ” said [Elinor]21-elinor . But [Laura]26-laura , speaking almost at the same time , said , “[434-you] [You]434-you were not alone , then ; [you]434-you ca n’t deny it , [Elinor]21-elinor . [You]434-you went there to meet [somebody]376-somebody . ” [Elinor]21-elinor answered nothing , but bent [her]21-elinor head over [her]21-elinor sewing , and had the tears in [her]21-elinor eyes . [Mr. Chanson]37-mr. chanson was almost as much embar‐ rassed as [she]26-laura . [He]37-mr. chanson rose up , crushed the newspaper , and turning [his]37-mr. chanson back , leaned on the mantel‐shelf , taking part in [his]37-mr. chanson own heat with [the embarrassed young girl]1507-the embarrassed young girl , against [[his]37-mr. chanson sister]1508-his sister , though the latter was clearly in the right . “[376-somebody] Was it [Mr. Leslie]24-leslie ? ” said [Laura]26-laura . “[24-leslie] Oh ! [Mr. Leslie]24-leslie ! ” said [[her]26-laura brother]195-her brother , half turning round ; “[24-leslie] quite impossible . ” [Laura]26-laura could not be quite sure it was [he]24-leslie , for though , indeed , the broken seal of [Elinor]21-elinor ’s letter had revealed the intercourse between [them]1510-them , [she]26-laura could not comprehend by what means [he]24-leslie could so rapidly have obeyed the summons ; yet [she]26-laura could not but feel it must be [Leslie]24-leslie , and [her]26-laura anxiety and dread about it were extreme . “[21-elinor] Speak , [Elinor]21-elinor ! say whether or not it was [he]24-leslie . ” “[24-leslie] No , no , ” said [Mr. Chanson]37-mr. chanson ; “[24-leslie] there is no sense in asking such a thing . [I]0-i had a letter from [him]24-leslie two days ago , about [the distemper‐powders]440-the distemper‐powders ; [he]24-leslie was not going from [home]139-home — besides ...... ” What there was besides [he]24-leslie did not explain , but [Elinor]21-elinor took courage under this unexpected defence , and though [she]21-elinor would not say a word of denial [herself]21-elinor , felt half justified by the denial [he]24-leslie extemporised , and sewed away , supported in the silence [she]21-elinor resolved to observe . [Laura]26-laura , on the other hand , was unduly discouraged , and [her]26-laura pressing investigation , which must have ended in a victory , resulted in an impatient “[21-elinor] Well ! ” and [the three]1511-the three sat in the most uncomfortable silence , till [Elinor]21-elinor , who felt thoroughly humble , and anxious to do something right , though [she]21-elinor could not do the one right thing [they]1511-the three wanted , so anxiously watched [her]21-elinor chances of finding [the Squire]1324-the squire ’s spectacles , picking up [his]24-leslie book , and placing it softly on the table when it fell out of [his]24-leslie slumbering hand , of remembering where [Laura]26-laura had laid down the key of the tea‐chest , of letting [Puff]45-master puff out of [the room]104-the room , and letting [him]24-leslie in again , that [Mr. Chanson]37-mr. chanson ’s heart was quite softened , and gently touching [her]442-you head , [he]37-mr. chanson said , in a low voice , “[21-elinor] [You]442-you are [a good little girl]443-a good little girl — only mind what [Laura]26-laura tells [you]442-you ; ” and [Elinor]21-elinor was so pleased with the kind words , that [she]21-elinor felt as if [she]21-elinor should never obey [anybody else]1514-anybody else , nor perhaps would [she]21-elinor , had there been as much womanly kindness and sincerity in [the sister]1515-the sister as of gentleness in [the brother]1516-the brother . But [Laura]26-laura had feelings quite apart from the interests of [Elinor]21-elinor , which prevented any approach to kindliness , and those were [her]21-elinor own concern in [Leslie]24-leslie , and in all that [he]24-leslie did . [He]24-leslie had secured a place in [her]21-elinor affections such as [he]24-leslie never aspired to , and which , at this time , [he]24-leslie would much rather have been without ; and it made [Laura]26-laura wild with jealousy to think that one day [Elinor]21-elinor might occupy the place which [she]21-elinor [herself]21-elinor , with all [her]21-elinor beauty , wit , and wealth , longed for in vain . Should [those two]1517-those two be coming and going together , civil to [her]21-elinor , but [lovers of each other]1518-lovers of each other ? should it be by short and transient fits that [she]21-elinor should see [Leslie]24-leslie , but [Elinor]21-elinor be of [[his]24-leslie house]1519-his house , always [his]24-leslie and with [him]24-leslie ? should [the stranger]1520-the stranger ’s sustained attention be for [her]21-elinor , but the word , the sign , the look , the understood gesture , be for [Elinor]21-elinor ? [Laura]26-laura could not endure it , and the thing was so inadmissible , that whatever [she]26-laura could do to prevent it seemed the thing to be done — not the right thing , perhaps , but still to be done . [She]26-laura hated [Elinor]21-elinor , and would willingly have seen in [her]26-laura all those defects which would disenchant [Leslie]24-leslie ; [she]26-laura wished they were in [her]26-laura , and acknowledged to be there by [everybody]1226-everybody ; and when [Elinor]21-elinor had gently crept out of [the room]104-the room , at an early bedtime , [she]21-elinor broke the long silence that had descended upon [them]1523-them all , and began to talk in an ingenuous , candid tone , to [[her]21-elinor brother]195-her brother . “[26-laura] There are great excuses to be made for [that poor child]444-that poor child , ” said [she]21-elinor . “[26-laura] The liberty [she]444-that poor child enjoys is so sudden , and the training [she]444-that poor child has had is so bad , that [she]444-that poor child is liable to errors from which [other people]210-other people are free . ” “[26-laura] Yes , indeed , ” said [the Squire]1324-the squire ; “[26-laura] and it is very kind and just of [you]446-you , [Laura]26-laura , to make excuses for [her]444-that poor child . [She]444-that poor child wants [a friend]350-a friend . ” “[444-that poor child] Yes ! [I]0-i only wish [she]444-that poor child were more willing to listen to [me]0-i . ” “[444-that poor child] [She]444-that poor child is a little wilful , is [she]444-that poor child ? ” “[444-that poor child] [I]0-i think [you]0-i must have perceived that . Do n’t [you]0-i see how [she]444-that poor child keeps apart all the morning ?
